How You Get Stronger
There are no levels. There is no XP track. There is no number that ticks up after each session telling you itâ€™s time to pick a new ability.
Your credits are your experience points. Every credit you earn is a choice:

â€¢ Spend it on an augment â†’ you get stronger  â€¢ Spend it on scar treatment â†’ you stay alive  â€¢ Spend it on rent â†’ you have somewhere to sleep  â€¢ Spend it on ammo â†’ you can fight next mission  â€¢ Spend it on the base â†’ the whole team benefits long-term  â€¢ Save it â†’ youâ€™re closer to the next big purchase

Progression in Arcane Steel is economic. You advance by surviving missions, earning pay, and choosing where to invest. A contractor who spends every credit on augments is powerful but lives on the street with untreated scars. A contractor who plays it safe has a nice apartment and zero upgrades. Neither extreme works. The game lives in the tension between them.
Stat Growth

Your starting stats arenâ€™t your final stats. Contractors grow through training, experience, and (for those who push past human limits) augmentation. Stats advance through three bands, each with its own method:
Band 1: Training (Stats 1-6)

Any stat can be trained up to 6 through downtime investment. This is the slow, reliable method â€” grinding reps at the range, studying at a terminal, working with Ratch at the Yard, sparring at the Grindhouse.
Current Stat Training Cost AP Required
1 â†’ 2                   100 cr                  6 AP (2 days)
2 â†’ 3                   150 cr                  9 AP (3 days)

4 â†’ 5                   300 cr                  18 AP (6 days)
Soft cap: 6. Training alone cannot push a stat past 6. Six is competent. Six is â€œgood at this.â€œ Beyond 6 requires experience that canâ€™t be taught in a gym.

Training is cumulative â€” you donâ€™t need to do all the AP in one stretch. Track training progress between sessions. A player who dedicates 3 AP per downtime period to training Chrome from 4 to 5 finishes in 6 downtime periods (18 AP total).

This is how a negotiator shores up weaknesses. The Edge 7 / Chrome 3 character trains Chrome to 5 over a few weeks of downtime. Theyâ€™re still not a bruiser, but they can carry their own gear and wear real armor. The cost: 450 cr and 27 AP across the campaign. Thatâ€™s a meaningful investment that competes with augments, skills, and base contributions.
Band 2: Mission Credits (Stats 7-10)

Beyond 6, improvement comes from doing the work. Certain missions push you past what training can achieve â€” the contract that forces you to dig deeper, fight harder, think faster, or talk your way out of something impossible.

Stat Credits are awarded by the GM at the end of qualifying missions. Not every mission qualifies â€” routine extraction doesnâ€™t test your limits. The contracts that earn Stat Credits are the ones that push the crew:

â€¢ Completing a contract above the crewâ€™s usual threat tier  â€¢ Surviving a situation where the odds were genuinely against them  â€¢ Achieving a mission objective through exceptional skill or creativity  â€¢ Story-significant missions that change the crewâ€™s situation
Rate guidance for GMs: Roughly 1 Stat Credit per 3-5 sessions. Enough to matter, rare enough to feel earned. Over a 20-session campaign, thatâ€™s 4-7 Stat Credits total.
A Stat Credit is a coupon. When the GM awards one, the player receives it and holds it. They can cash it in at any time for +1 to any stat (max 10). The credit doesnâ€™t expire. A player can:

â€¢ Spend it immediately to patch a weakness from 3 to 4  â€¢ Hold it until theyâ€™ve trained a stat to 6, then push to 7  â€¢ Stockpile 2-3 credits and dump them all at once for a dramatic jump  â€¢ Save it for the perfect moment when one stat point changes everything

Installation: Stat Credits are cashed in at a clinic during downtime. No installation fee â€” this isnâ€™t surgery, itâ€™s acknowledging growth that already happened in the field. Vasik updates your file. The number changes. Youâ€™re better than you were.

The Secondary Market: Stat Credits are transferable. A contractor who earned a credit but doesnâ€™t need it can sell it, trade it, or gift it. The price is whatever the market bears â€” expect 500-1,000 cr depending on demand, scarcity, and how good the buyerâ€™s Face is at negotiating. Finding a seller requires asking around (Streetwise check at the Grindhouse, the Market, or through broker contacts). Finding a seller with a fair price requires Edge.

This means Stat Credits feed back into the economic loop. Need a point but canâ€™t wait to earn one? Find a seller. Canâ€™t afford the sellerâ€™s price? Take a contract. One more job. Always one more job.
Natural cap: 10. Stats cannot exceed 10 through training or mission credits. Ten is peak human â€” the absolute ceiling of what the unaugmented body and mind can achieve. Beyond 10 requires chrome.
Band 3: Augmented Stats (Stats 11-15)
Augments can push stats past human limits. This is the domain of specialized augment modifications â€” not standard tree augments, but dedicated Stat Enhancement Augments that rewrite your biology.
Cost: Stat Enhancement Augments cost 1,500 cr per point above 10, plus installation.

Disruption: Every point above 10 causes -2 to another stat of the playerâ€™s choice (minimum). The body can only handle so much enhancement before something else gives. The augments that push your Chrome to 12 displace something â€” maybe your reflexes slow as your muscles bulk beyond natural proportions, or your social intuition dulls as your neural pathways rewire for pure physical processing.

Example: A Chrome 10 contractor wants Chrome 12. Cost: 3,000 cr (1,500 Ã— 2). They assign the -4 disruption: -2 Edge, -2 Interface. Their social skills and rift attunement suffer as their body becomes increasingly machine. They swing harder than anyone alive. They canâ€™t read a room or cast a pattern anymore.

Example: An Interface 10 channeler pushes to Interface 13. Cost: 4,500 cr. Disruption: -6 total. They assign -2 Chrome, -2 Reflex, -2 Grit. Theyâ€™re the most powerful rift caster on the continent. A stiff breeze could kill them. They need the team more than ever.
Disruption cannot reduce a stat below 1. If youâ€™re already at stat 2 and assign -2, it drops to 1 (minimum). You cannot zero out a stat.

The trade-off is the point. Pushing past 10 is a statement about who your character is becoming. The Chrome 14 brute isnâ€™t a well-rounded contractor anymore â€” theyâ€™re a weapon with legs, dependent on their crew for everything their atrophied stats canâ€™t handle. The team doesnâ€™t just benefit from specialization; they become essential to the specialistâ€™s survival.

The journey from 5 to 6 costs time and money. The journey from 6 to 10 costs missions and courage. The journey from 10 to 15 costs âˆ—yourself.
What â€œLeveling Upâ€œ Looks Like

â€¢ Stat Growth â€” train weaknesses, earn mission credits, push limits with augments. â€¢ Augment Trees â€” buy augments, climb tiers, unlock mastery passives. This is your primary power progression. â€¢ Skill Training â€” spend downtime AP on learning. Skills advance through the LP system (see Downtime: Learning & Advancement). â€¢ Gear â€” better weapons, better armor, a vehicle that hauls more. Bought with credits. â€¢ The Base â€” long-term team investment that compounds returns over the campaign.

The result: Two contractors who started identical can look completely different by session 10. One went deep into Fury with six augments and lives in a Capsule. The other spread across three trees, invested in the teamâ€™s base, and has a Workshop. One trained their Edge to 6 and cashed two mission credits to push to 8, becoming the crewâ€™s face. The other dumped three credits into Chrome and is eyeing the 11+ augments. Both are â€œlevel 10â€œ in a sense. Neither looks anything like the other.
Thereâ€™s no level cap. Thereâ€™s just how much you can afford before the world kills you.
